questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presents to your office with primary amenorrhea. She has normal breast and pubic hair development. But the uterus and vagina are absent. The most likely possibility is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘C‘ Mullerian agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome): It presents as amenorrhea with absence of a vagina
  • ➤ The karyotype is 46 XX. There is normal development of breasts, sexual hair, ovaries, external genitalia. There are associated urinary tract (33%) and skeletal (12%) anomalies.
  • ➤ The karyotype is 46 XX.
  • ➤ There is normal development of breasts, sexual hair, ovaries, external genitalia.
  • ➤ There are associated urinary tract (33%) and skeletal (12%) anomalies.
  • ➤ The best way to differentiate between Mullerian agenesis and Androgen Insensitivity syndrome is to get a karyotype.
  • ➤ Mullerian agenesis is 46XX Androgen Insensitivity is 46 XY
  • ➤ Mullerian agenesis is 46XX
  • ➤ Androgen Insensitivity is 46 XY
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 44, Textbook of Gynecology by DC Dutta, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 44, Textbook of Gynecology by DC Dutta, 6 th edition

questions.text: The most common Mullerian anomaly is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘D’ Septate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septate uterus is the most common Mullerian anomaly
  • ➤ WHO classification of Mullerian anomalies
  • ➤ Class I = Mullerian agenesis (MRKH) Class II = Unicornuate uterus (10%) Class III = Didelphys uterus (complete duplication: two uteri, two cervices, and longitudinal vaginal septum (8%) Class IV = Bicornuate uterus (26%) Class V = Septate uterus (35%) Class VI = Arcuate uterus (18%) Class VII = DES-related abnormalities/T-shaped uterus
  • ➤ Class I = Mullerian agenesis (MRKH)
  • ➤ Class II = Unicornuate uterus (10%)
  • ➤ Class III = Didelphys uterus (complete duplication: two uteri, two cervices, and longitudinal vaginal septum (8%)
  • ➤ Class IV = Bicornuate uterus (26%)
  • ➤ Class V = Septate uterus (35%)
  • ➤ Class VI = Arcuate uterus (18%)
  • ➤ Class VII = DES-related abnormalities/T-shaped uterus
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 44, Textbook of Gynecology by DC Dutta, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 44, Textbook of Gynecology by DC Dutta, 6 th edition

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the following imaging?

options.label: A
options.text: It is 2 nd most common mullerian anomaly

options.label: B
options.text: The given investigation is considered ix of choice for mullerian anomalies

questions.correct_answer: D. It can be treated hysteroscopically
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘D’It can be treated hysteroscopically.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an HSG image showing a septate uterus (inter cornual angle < 70 0 ) It is the most common mullerian anomaly. It has poor reproductive outcome. HSG is not a good investigation for Mullerian anomalies. The best non-invasive ix of choice for Mullerian anomaly is an MRI. Treatment is hysteroscopic septal resection.

  • • It has poor reproductive outcome.

  • • The best non-invasive ix of choice for Mullerian anomaly is an MRI.

It has poor reproductive outcome.

questions.text: Complete failure of mullerian duct fusion will result in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘A’ Uterus didelphys

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The two Mullerian ducts fuse to form the complete uterus. The anomalies can arise because of vertical or lateral fusion The Mullerian ducts come into being at around 6 weeks and failure to appear will lead to uterine aplasia. The fusing mullerian ducts form a singular cavity after dissolution of the septa Failure of resorption of the midline septum leads to formation of uterine septum which can be of full length i.e. from the
  • ➤ The two Mullerian ducts fuse to form the complete uterus.
  • ➤ The anomalies can arise because of vertical or lateral fusion
  • ➤ The Mullerian ducts come into being at around 6 weeks and failure to appear will lead to uterine aplasia.
  • ➤ The fusing mullerian ducts form a singular cavity after dissolution of the septa
  • ➤ Failure of resorption of the midline septum leads to formation of uterine septum which can be of full length i.e. from the
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 8 th edition

questions.text: While evaluating a 30-year-old woman for infertility, you diagnose a bicornuate uterus. You explain that additional testing is necessary for one organ system because of the woman’s increased risk of congenital anomalies. Which is that organ system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘C’ Urinary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Failed fusion of the Mullerian ducts can give rise to several types of uterine anomalies, e.g., bicornuate uterus. This condition is associated with a higher risk of obstetric complications, such as an increase in the rate of second-trimester abortion and premature labor. An intravenous pyelogram or urinary tract ultrasound is mandatory in patients with Mullerian anomalies, since approximately 30-40%% of patients with Mullerian anomalies have coexisting congenital urinary tract anomalies. Other associated abnormalities: skeletal (!2%)
  • ➤ Failed fusion of the Mullerian ducts can give rise to several types of uterine anomalies, e.g., bicornuate uterus.
  • ➤ This condition is associated with a higher risk of obstetric complications, such as an increase in the rate of second-trimester abortion and premature labor.
  • ➤ An intravenous pyelogram or urinary tract ultrasound is mandatory in patients with Mullerian anomalies, since approximately 30-40%% of patients with Mullerian anomalies have coexisting congenital urinary tract anomalies.
  • ➤ Other associated abnormalities: skeletal (!2%)
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome is associated with?
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘C’ Vaginal atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic feature of MRKH syndrome (Mullerian agenesis) is absent uterus, absent fallopian tubes, absent cervix and absent upper part of vagina, absent

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent abortions. USG reveals a septate uterus. What is the best management for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. is ‘D’ Transcervical resection of septum.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women with septate uterus who are candidates for surgical repair, hysteroscopic (transcervical) metroplasty/ septal resection is the procedure of choice.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose uni-cornuate uterus? I. HSG II. Xray Pelvis III. Laparoscopy IV. CT scan
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. I & III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Depending on a woman’s initial complaint, tools to diagnose Müllerian anomalies may include hysterosalpingography (HSG), sonography (Especially 3D USG), MR imaging, laparoscopy, and hysteroscopy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 14-year girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She complains of monthly abdominal pain since a few months. On examination, there is a suprapubic bulge. The vaginal appears blind but she does not allow a vaginal or rectal exam to be done. Which of the following is NOT a possibility?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. MRKH Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An obstructive Mullerian anomaly like cervical agensesis, transverse vaginal septum, imperforate hymen will present with hematocolpos/ hematometra and features of endometriosis
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 24-year woman presents with recurrent mid trimester losses. A 3-D scan is ordered which shows the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a 3D scan showing bicornuate uterus. A 3D scan differentiates between bicornuate and septate uterus much better than an HSG The main confusion is between a bicornuate and a septate uterus.
  • • This is a 3D scan showing bicornuate uterus.
  • • A 3D scan differentiates between bicornuate and septate uterus much better than an HSG
  • • The main confusion is between a bicornuate and a septate uterus.
  • • On a 3D scan,
  • • A line is traced joining both horns of the uterine cavity. If this line crossed the fundus or is ⩽ 5 mm from it, the uterus is considered bicornuate (a and b) If it is >5 mm from the fundus it was considered septate, regardless of whether the fundus was dome-shaped, smooth or discretely notched
  • • A line is traced joining both horns of the uterine cavity.
  • • If this line crossed the fundus or is ⩽ 5 mm from it, the uterus is considered bicornuate (a and b)
  • • If it is >5 mm from the fundus it was considered septate, regardless of whether the fundus was dome-shaped, smooth or discretely notched
  • • On HSG, to differentiate between the two, it is important to not that
  • • In septate uterus, the inter-cornual angle < 75 ° In bicornuate uterus, the inter-cornual angle > 105 °
  • • In septate uterus, the inter-cornual angle < 75 °
  • • In bicornuate uterus, the inter-cornual angle > 105 °
  • • Septate Uterus
  • • Bicornuate Uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The OHVIRA syndrome is seen in which type of Mullerian Anomaly?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Uterine Didelphys is associated with Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA) This is called the OHVIRA syndrome
  • • Uterine Didelphys is associated with Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • • Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • • Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV)
  • • Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • • This is called the OHVIRA syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine Didelphys is associated with Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA) This is called the OHVIRA syndrome
  • ➤ Uterine Didelphys is associated with Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • ➤ Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV) Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • ➤ Obstructed Hemi-vagina (OHV)
  • ➤ Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (IRA)
  • ➤ This is called the OHVIRA syndrome

questions.text: A 13-year-old female presents with increasing abdominal pain. She has begun appropriate pubertal development, although menarche has not occurred. During examination, a central abdominopelvic mass is appreciated and is shown in the image. Physical examination findings prompt sonography and then magnetic resonance (MR) imaging with contrast. The MR imaging results are shown in the 2 nd Figure. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?

options.label: D
options.text: Obstructed hemi-vagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a case of imperforate hymen. On the MRI, a large hematocolpos is seen (blood collected in the vagina) Treatment is by incising the imperforate hymen by a cruciate incision and draining the hamatocolpos
  • • This is a case of imperforate hymen.
  • • On the MRI, a large hematocolpos is seen (blood collected in the vagina)
  • • Treatment is by incising the imperforate hymen by a cruciate incision and draining the hamatocolpos
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Mullerian agenesis: As there is no uterus or vagina, there is no collection of blood (no hematocolpos or hematometra) Option B: Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, there will be hematometra (collection of blood in the uterus_. Not hematocolpos. Option D: Obstructed hemi-vagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome : This will present in a didelphys uterus where there is an bstructed hemo vagina. So there will be partial hematocolpos but she will not have primary amenorrhoea (would have attained menarche) as the obstruction in the vagina is partial
  • • Option A: Mullerian agenesis: As there is no uterus or vagina, there is no collection of blood (no hematocolpos or hematometra)
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, there will be hematometra (collection of blood in the uterus_. Not hematocolpos.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Obstructed hemi-vagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome : This will present in a didelphys uterus where there is an bstructed hemo vagina. So there will be partial hematocolpos but she will not have primary amenorrhoea (would have attained menarche) as the obstruction in the vagina is partial
  • • Option D:
  • • :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An imperforate hymen will present as primary amenorrhoea with secondary sexual characters with cyclical abdominal pain O/e: bluish bulge at introitus, abdominal pulge (hematocolpos/ hematometra) MRI will show a hematocolpos with the obstruction low down
  • ➤ An imperforate hymen will present as primary amenorrhoea with secondary sexual characters with cyclical abdominal pain
  • ➤ O/e: bluish bulge at introitus, abdominal pulge (hematocolpos/ hematometra)
  • ➤ MRI will show a hematocolpos with the obstruction low down
  • ➤ Ref: Page 444, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 444, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: What is the preferred imaging modality when a congenital mullerian anomaly is suspected?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • MR imaging is currently preferred or imaging complex defects MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent in the evaluation of Müllerian anomalies Moreover, complex anomalies and commonly associated secondary diagnoses such as renal or skeletal anomalies can be concurrently evaluated. In some women undergoing an in fertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy may be selected to assess or Müllerian anomalies; screen or endometriosis, which is often coexistent; and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathologies
  • • MR imaging is currently preferred or imaging complex defects
  • • MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent in the evaluation of Müllerian anomalies
  • • Moreover, complex anomalies and commonly associated secondary diagnoses such as renal or skeletal anomalies can be concurrently evaluated.
  • • In some women undergoing an in fertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy may be selected to assess or Müllerian anomalies; screen or endometriosis, which is often coexistent; and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathologies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MR imaging is currently preferred or imaging complex defects MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent in the evaluation of Müllerian anomalies
  • ➤ MR imaging is currently preferred or imaging complex defects
  • ➤ MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent in the evaluation of Müllerian anomalies
  • ➤ Ref: Page 445, William Gynecology, 3 rd edition

questions.text: You are presented with a patient with a Unicornuate uterus that is similar in shape to the one shown here. What is the next appropriate step in your management?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Müllerian defects are associated with renal anomalies in 30 to 50 percent of cases, and defects include unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney, and ectopic or duplicate ureters Spinal anomalies have been reported in 10 to 12 percent of cases and include wedge, supernumerary, or asymmetric and rudimentary vertebral bodies The combination of Müllerian and renal aplasia and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia has been described as MURCS association An association with Klippel-Feil syndrome has also been reported. Other anomalies associated with vaginal agenesis include ear anomalies and hearing loss
  • • Müllerian defects are associated with renal anomalies in 30 to 50 percent of cases, and defects include unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney, and ectopic or duplicate ureters
  • • Spinal anomalies have been reported in 10 to 12 percent of cases and include wedge, supernumerary, or asymmetric and rudimentary vertebral bodies
  • • The combination of Müllerian and renal aplasia and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia has been described as MURCS association
  • • An association with Klippel-Feil syndrome has also been reported.
  • • Other anomalies associated with vaginal agenesis include ear anomalies and hearing loss
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B: Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is not indicated as it will not provide any additional information and a diagnostic hystero-laparoscopy is done only whent he diagnosis is in doubt Option C: Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This is not indicated as it will not provide any additional information and a diagnostic hystero-laparoscopy is done only whent he diagnosis is in doubt Option D: Brain MRI: This is not indicated in Mullerian anomalies
  • • Option B: Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is not indicated as it will not provide any additional information and a diagnostic hystero-laparoscopy is done only whent he diagnosis is in doubt
  • • Option C: Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This is not indicated as it will not provide any additional information and a diagnostic hystero-laparoscopy is done only whent he diagnosis is in doubt
  • • Option D: Brain MRI: This is not indicated in Mullerian anomalies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Müllerian defects are associated with renal anomalies in 30 to 50 percent of cases, and defects include unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney, and ectopic or duplicate ureters Spinal anomalies have been reported in 10 to 12 percent of cases and include wedge, supernumerary, or asymmetric and rudimentary vertebral bodies The combination of Müllerian and renal aplasia and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia has been described as MURCS association An association with Klippel-Feil syndrome has also been reported. Other anomalies associated with vaginal agenesis include ear anomalies and hearing loss
  • ➤ Müllerian defects are associated with renal anomalies in 30 to 50 percent of cases, and defects include unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, horseshoe kidney, pelvic kidney, and ectopic or duplicate ureters
  • ➤ Spinal anomalies have been reported in 10 to 12 percent of cases and include wedge, supernumerary, or asymmetric and rudimentary vertebral bodies
  • ➤ The combination of Müllerian and renal aplasia and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia has been described as MURCS association
  • ➤ An association with Klippel-Feil syndrome has also been reported.
  • ➤ Other anomalies associated with vaginal agenesis include ear anomalies and hearing loss
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 445, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 445, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old G3P0 presents to your office as a new patient for consultation regarding her history of multiple miscarriages. Her gynecologic history is otherwise unremarkable. During physical examination, you note that the uterus is markedly deviated to the left. Transvaginal sonography is performed, and three-dimensional images reveal a single uterus that is deviated and has a banana-shaped cavity, as shown below? What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a patient with unicornuate uterus. With Unicornuate uterus, a functional uterus, normal cervix, and normal round ligament and fallopian tube are found on one side. On the contralateral side, Müllerian structures develop abnormally, and agenesis or more frequently a rudimentary uterine horn is identified. A rudimentary horn may communicate or more commonly not communicate with the unicornuate uterus. In addition, the endometrial cavity of the rudimentary horn may be obliterated or may contain some functioning endometrium. Active endometrium in a noncommunicating horn will eventually be symptomatic with cyclic unilateral pain and possibly with hematometra.
  • • This is a patient with unicornuate uterus.
  • • With Unicornuate uterus, a functional uterus, normal cervix, and normal round ligament and fallopian tube are found on one side.
  • • On the contralateral side, Müllerian structures develop abnormally, and agenesis or more frequently a rudimentary uterine horn is identified.
  • • A rudimentary horn may communicate or more commonly not communicate with the unicornuate uterus.
  • • In addition, the endometrial cavity of the rudimentary horn may be obliterated or may contain some functioning endometrium.
  • • Active endometrium in a noncommunicating horn will eventually be symptomatic with cyclic unilateral pain and possibly with hematometra.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Septate uterus: This presents as poor reproductive outcome. On an HSG, the 2 uterine horns, the angle will be < 75 degree Option B: Bicornuate uterus: This presents as a wide intercornual angle on the HSG Option C: Didelphys: This presents as 2 completely seprate uterine covities which are far apart
  • • Option A: Septate uterus: This presents as poor reproductive outcome. On an HSG, the 2 uterine horns, the angle will be < 75 degree
  • • Option A: Septate uterus:
  • • Option B: Bicornuate uterus: This presents as a wide intercornual angle on the HSG
  • • Option B: Bicornuate uterus:
  • • Option C: Didelphys: This presents as 2 completely seprate uterine covities which are far apart
  • • Option C: Didelphys:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On a 3D scan,
  • ➤ A line is traced joining both horns of the uterine cavity. If this line crossed the fundus or is ⩽5 mm from it, the uterus is considered bicornuate (a and b) If it is >5 mm from the fundus it was considered septate, regardless of whether the fundus was dome-shaped, smooth or discretely notched
  • ➤ A line is traced joining both horns of the uterine cavity.
  • ➤ If this line crossed the fundus or is ⩽5 mm from it, the uterus is considered bicornuate (a and b)
  • ➤ If it is >5 mm from the fundus it was considered septate, regardless of whether the fundus was dome-shaped, smooth or discretely notched
  • ➤ On HSG, to differentiate between the two, it is important to not that
  • ➤ In septate uterus, the inter-cornual angle < 75 ° In bicornuate uterus, the inter-cornual angle > 105 °
  • ➤ In septate uterus, the inter-cornual angle < 75 °
  • ➤ In bicornuate uterus, the inter-cornual angle > 105 °
  • ➤ Septate Uterus
  • ➤ Bicornuate Uterus

questions.text: Which of the mullerian anomalies, as illustrated in this sonogram, has the best reproductive prognosis? A gestational sac is seen on the image’s left?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Of the major uterine malformations, the didelphic uterus has a good reproductive prognosis. Compared with the unicornuate uterus, although the potential or uterine growth and capacity appears similar, uterine didelphys probably has an improved blood supply from collateral connections between the two horns.
  • • Of the major uterine malformations, the didelphic uterus has a good reproductive prognosis.
  • • Compared with the unicornuate uterus, although the potential or uterine growth and capacity appears similar, uterine didelphys probably has an improved blood supply from collateral connections between the two horns.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Of the major uterine malformations, the didelphic uterus has a good reproductive prognosis. An arcuate uterus also will not usually present with any major complication
  • ➤ Of the major uterine malformations, the didelphic uterus has a good reproductive prognosis.
  • ➤ An arcuate uterus also will not usually present with any major complication
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 448, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 448, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: When should surgical reconstruction of a bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) be performed?

options.label: B
options.text: In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus

options.label: D
options.text: For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly

questions.correct_answer: D. For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Surgical reconstruction of the bicornuate uterus is infrequently done in bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) and is been advocated in women with multiple spontaneous abortions in whom no other causative actors are identified. Strassman described the surgical technique that unified equal-sized endometrial cavities. Reproductive outcome after unification generally has been good. As in surgery or uterine didelphys, metroplasty is reserved or women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause.
  • • Surgical reconstruction of the bicornuate uterus is infrequently done in bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) and is been advocated in women with multiple spontaneous abortions in whom no other causative actors are identified.
  • • Strassman described the surgical technique that unified equal-sized endometrial cavities.
  • • Reproductive outcome after unification generally has been good.
  • • As in surgery or uterine didelphys, metroplasty is reserved or women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause.
  • • Let's discuss the other options:
  • • Let's discuss the other options:
  • • Option A: Only for complete bicornuate anomalies: This is incorrect. It is performed only for those bicornuate uterus where ther eis no other reason for pregnancy loss Option B: In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus. This is also incorrect. Option C: Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus. This is also incorrect. The surgery for bicornuate uterus is Strassman metroplasty.
  • • Option A: Only for complete bicornuate anomalies: This is incorrect. It is performed only for those bicornuate uterus where ther eis no other reason for pregnancy loss
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus. This is also incorrect.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus. This is also incorrect. The surgery for bicornuate uterus is Strassman metroplasty.
  • • Option C:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical reconstruction of the bicornuate uterus is infrequently done in bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) and is been advocated in women with multiple spontaneous abortions in whom no other causative actors are identified.
  • ➤ Surgical reconstruction of the bicornuate uterus is infrequently done in bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) and is been advocated in women with multiple spontaneous abortions in whom no other causative actors are identified.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 449, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 449, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Septate uterus has a significantly higher spontaneous abortion rate and early pregnancy loss rate than bicornuate uterus. As illustrated in the figure below, what is the primary mechanism thought to be responsible for this extraordinarily high pregnancy wastage?

options.label: C
options.text: Distortion of the uterine serosal contour

options.label: D
options.text: Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum

questions.correct_answer: D. Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • High pregnancy wastage likely results from partial or complete implantation on a largely avascular septum, from distortion of the uterine cavity, and from associated cervical or endometrial abnormalities.
  • • High pregnancy wastage likely results from partial or complete implantation on a largely avascular septum, from distortion of the uterine cavity, and from associated cervical or endometrial abnormalities.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Complications associated with a septate uterus are: Infertility Recurent pregnancy loss Fetal growth restriciton Intra uterine fetal demise Malpresentations Preterm labor

questions.text: Which of the following are seen in offspring of women who took diethylstilbestrol (DES)? Impaired conception rates in female offspring Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, and malformations of the penis in male offspring T-shaped uterus “Cockscomb” cervix Increased rates of clear cell adenocarcinoma in female offspring
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES), a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen, was prescribed to an estimated 3 million pregnant women in the United States from the late 1940s through the early 1960s. The drug was used in treating abortion, preeclampsia, diabetes, hot flushes, and preterm labor. DES exposure in utero has been linked to the development of a “T-shaped” uterus An increased incidence of clear cell adenocarcinomas of the vagina and cervix. Vaginal and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Genitourinary malformations following DES exposure in utero have also been noted and include those of the cervix, vagina, uterine cavity, and fallopian tubes. transverse septa, circumferential ridges involving the vagina and cervix, and cervical collars (“cockscomb cervix”) have been found. Fallopian tube abnormalities include shortened and narrowed dimensions and absent fimbria. Males exposed to DES in utero also have structural abnormalities. Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, microphallus, and hypospadias have been reported.
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES), a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen, was prescribed to an estimated 3 million pregnant women in the United States from the late 1940s through the early 1960s.

Vaginal and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Genitourinary malformations following DES exposure in utero have also been noted and include those of the cervix, vagina, uterine cavity, and fallopian tubes. transverse septa, circumferential ridges involving the vagina and cervix, and cervical collars (“cockscomb cervix”) have been found. Fallopian tube abnormalities include shortened and narrowed dimensions and absent fimbria. Males exposed to DES in utero also have structural abnormalities. Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, microphallus, and hypospadias have been reported.
  • • the development of a “T-shaped” uterus An increased incidence of clear cell adenocarcinomas of the vagina and cervix. Vaginal and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Genitourinary malformations following DES exposure in utero have also been noted and include those of the cervix, vagina, uterine cavity, and fallopian tubes. transverse septa, circumferential ridges involving the vagina and cervix, and cervical collars (“cockscomb cervix”) have been found. Fallopian tube abnormalities include shortened and narrowed dimensions and absent fimbria. Males exposed to DES in utero also have structural abnormalities. Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, microphallus, and hypospadias have been reported.
  • • the development of a “T-shaped” uterus
  • • An increased incidence of clear cell adenocarcinomas of the vagina and cervix.
  • • Vaginal and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia,
  • • Genitourinary malformations following DES exposure in utero have also been noted and include those of the cervix, vagina, uterine cavity, and fallopian tubes. transverse septa, circumferential ridges involving the vagina and cervix, and cervical collars (“cockscomb cervix”) have been found.
  • • Fallopian tube abnormalities include shortened and narrowed dimensions and absent fimbria.
  • • Males exposed to DES in utero also have structural abnormalities. Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, microphallus, and hypospadias have been reported.
